author: Coreena Ford
title: More than 1,000 jobs planned in Port of Tyne energy plant scheme
text:
More than 1,000 jobs planned in Port of Tyne energy plant scheme 16:13, 29 Sep 2016 Plans for the renewable energy plant at Wallsend are to go on display to the public Share Get business news by email How the proposed energy plant at Howdon would look 
More than 1,000 jobs could be created through a new renewable energy plant planned for North Tyneside . 
The Port of Tyne is seeking planning permission to develop a 25 megawatt power plant in Howdon , which would generate enough electricity to power 50,000 homes using technology that converts waste into energy. 
The project would create 470 jobs in construction, 50 new permanent jobs once in operation and 732 jobs in the regional supply chain. 
Consultations are now under way on the application to build the 25 megawatt power plant on the site of the former Howdon Yard. 
The proposals have the potential to regenerate a site that has not had a permanent use for decades, and is limited for other types of development due to its proximity to the Tyne Tunnel and other major utility service channels under the surface. 
The Port of Tyne said the proposals – due to go on show to the public next week – will also deliver the opportunity to use heat generated from the plant to create a direct heating scheme for a building or project nearby. 
Port of Tyne chief executive Andrew Moffat said: “This proposal would bring the site back into viable use, sustaining local employment and creating further economic benefits for the local economy. It would be an important contributor to the UK’s energy supply. 
“We are keen that the local community also benefits from this project not only in terms of the jobs being created but by other means and that’s why we are establishing a community fund specifically for the purpose of making a difference in the nearby local community.” Read More Construction firm Galliford Try brushes off Brexit with contracts worth £60m 
The proposed power plant uses gasification processes which turn waste into gas without actually burning it. No waste externally would be stored on the site as it would be transported in sealed bales directly into the fully enclosed facility. 
The plant is designed to minimise any environmental impacts such as smell, dust or noise so that any potential emissions are well within national and European air quality standards. If plans are approved, the facility could be under construction by autumn 2017. 
The Port of Tyne will have the plans on display and the project team on hand to answer questions at East Howdon Community Centre on October 5 between 2.30 pm and 7pm.
